Funders for this research include Daewoo Shipbuilding& Marine Engineering; Ministry of Science, ICT and Future Planning; National IT Industry...
text:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Information
Technology Daily \-- Data detailed on information and data technologies have
been presented. According to news originating from Seoul National University
by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "To prevent pollution from ships,
the Energy Efficiency Index (EEDI) is a mandatory guideline for all new ships.
The Ship Energy Efficiency Management Plan (SEEMP) has also been applied by
MARPOL to all existing ships."

Funders for this research include Daewoo Shipbuilding & Marine Engineering;
Ministry of Science, ICT and Future Planning; National IT Industry Promotion
Agency; Seoul National University.

Our news editors obtained a quote from the research from Seoul National
University: "SEEMP provides the Energy Efficiency Operational Indicator (EEOI)
for monitoring the operational efficiency of a ship. By monitoring the EEOI,
the shipowner or operator can establish strategic plans, such as routing, hull
cleaning, decommissioning, new building, etc. The key parameter in calculating
EEOI is Fuel Oil Consumption (FOC). It can be measured on board while a ship
is operating. This means that only the shipowner or operator can calculate the
EEOI of their own ships. If the EEOI can be calculated without the actual FOC,
however, then the other stakeholders, such as the shipbuilding company and
Class, or others who don't have the measured FOC, can check how efficiently
their ships are operating compared to other ships. In this study, we propose a
method to estimate the EEOI without requiring the actual FOC. The Automatic
Identification System (AIS) data, ship static data, and environment data that
can be publicly obtained are used to calculate the EEOI."

According to the news editors, the research concluded: "Since the public data
are of large capacity, big data technologies, specifically Hadoop and Spark,
are used. We verify the proposed method using actual data, and the result
shows that the proposed method can estimate EEOI from public data without
actual FOC."

For more information on this research see: Estimation of ship operational
efficiency from AIS data using big data technology. _International Journal of
Naval Architecture and Ocean Engineering_ , 2020,12():440-454. (International
Journal of Naval Architecture and Ocean Engineering \-
<https://www.journals.elsevier.com/international-journal-of-naval-
architecture->). The publisher for International Journal of Naval Architecture
and Ocean Engineering is Elsevier.

A free version of this journal article is available at
<https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ijnaoe.2020.03.007>.

Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by
contacting Seong-Hoon Kim, Department of Naval Architecture and Ocean
Engineering, Seoul National University, South Korea. Additional authors for
this research include Myung-Il Roh, Min-Jae Oh, Sung-Woo Park, In-Il Kim.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around
the world.)

title: Study Results from Seoul National University in the Area of Information and Data Technologies Published (Estimation of ship operational efficiency from AIS data using big data technology): Information Technology - Information and Data Technologies
html:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Information Technology Daily -- Data detailed on information and data technologies have been presented. According to news originating from Seoul National University by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, “To prevent pollution from ships, the Energy Efficiency Index (EEDI) is a mandatory guideline for all new ships. The Ship Energy Efficiency Management Plan (SEEMP) has also been applied by MARPOL to all existing ships.”

Funders for this research include Daewoo Shipbuilding & Marine Engineering; Ministry of Science, ICT and Future Planning; National IT Industry Promotion Agency; Seoul National University.

Our news editors obtained a quote from the research from Seoul National University: “SEEMP provides the Energy Efficiency Operational Indicator (EEOI) for monitoring the operational efficiency of a ship. By monitoring the EEOI, the shipowner or operator can establish strategic plans, such as routing, hull cleaning, decommissioning, new building, etc. The key parameter in calculating EEOI is Fuel Oil Consumption (FOC). It can be measured on board while a ship is operating. This means that only the shipowner or operator can calculate the EEOI of their own ships. If the EEOI can be calculated without the actual FOC, however, then the other stakeholders, such as the shipbuilding company and Class, or others who don’t have the measured FOC, can check how efficiently their ships are operating compared to other ships. In this study, we propose a method to estimate the EEOI without requiring the actual FOC. The Automatic Identification System (AIS) data, ship static data, and environment data that can be publicly obtained are used to calculate the EEOI.”

According to the news editors, the research concluded: “Since the public data are of large capacity, big data technologies, specifically Hadoop and Spark, are used. We verify the proposed method using actual data, and the result shows that the proposed method can estimate EEOI from public data without actual FOC.”

For more information on this research see: Estimation of ship operational efficiency from AIS data using big data technology. International Journal of Naval Architecture and Ocean Engineering, 2020,12():440-454. (International Journal of Naval Architecture and Ocean Engineering - https://www.journals.elsevier.com/international-journal-of-naval-architecture-). The publisher for International Journal of Naval Architecture and Ocean Engineering is Elsevier.

A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ijnaoe.2020.03.007.

Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Seong-Hoon Kim, Department of Naval Architecture and Ocean Engineering, Seoul National University, South Korea. Additional authors for this research include Myung-Il Roh, Min-Jae Oh, Sung-Woo Park, In-Il Kim.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around the world.)
